questions.question: A 36-year-old pregnant woman with a history of gestational diabetes in her previous pregnancy presents for her routine prenatal visit at 32 weeks of gestation. She is concerned about her current baby's growth. Which of the following is most appropriate to assess fetal growth?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Growth Scan Explanation: USG is the most important investigation to assess fetal growth. Antepartum fetal surveillance of the third trimester: Clinical : Maternal weight Maternal BP Size of uterus Height of fundus Biochemical : Amniocentesis for assessing fetal pulmonary maturity Biophysical : Fetal movement count Ultrasonography Cardiotocography Nonstress test (NST) (Option A ruled out) Fetal biophysical profile (BPP) Doppler ultrasound (Option C ruled out) Vibroacoustic stimulation test Contraction stress test (CST) Amniotic fluid volume (Option D ruled out ) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 386-391. DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 96, 97, 99.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding nutritional status in pregnancy is true? pregnancy.

options.A: The increased calorie requirement is 400 kcal over the non pregnancy state during the second half of
options.B: The optimum weight gain during pregnancy is 10-12 kg for a normal BMI woman.
options.C: The daily dietary allowance of iron in lactating women is 200mcg.
options.D: Excessive weight gain decreases the intrapartum complications .

questions.explanation: woman. Correct Answer: B) The optimum weight gain during pregnancy is 10-12 kg for a normal BMI woman. Explanation: Pregnant women with a normal BMI (18.5–23 kg/m²) should aim to gain 10–12 kg. Underweight women (BMI <18.5 kg/m²) should increase their dietary intake and monitor their weight closely. Overweight (BMI 23–27.5 kg/m²) and obese women (BMI >27.5 kg/m²) should limit weight gain to 5–9 kg. During pregnancy, there is an increased need for calories and nutrients to support both the mother's health and the growth and development of the fetus due to: Maternal Tissue Growth Increased Metabolic Rate Nutrient Transfer to Fetus Preparation for Lactation Nutrition requirements: Calories During pregnancy + 350 kcal (Option A ruled out) During lactation +600Kcal in first 6 months of lactation(1-6M) +520Kcal in the next 6 months of lactation (7-12M) The recommended daily allowance (RDA) of iron for pregnant women is 27 milligrams, and for lactating women, 9 milligrams (Option C ruled out) . Reference: ttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6866113/

questions.question: A 26-year-old newly married woman came to the OPD with a positive urine pregnancy test. She has a history of antiepileptic drug usage for the past 5 years. Which of the following would you advise the patient? Anti-epileptic drug has to be continued Immediately stop the anti-epileptic once pregnancy is detected Folate supplementation of 4 mcg/day is given No anti-epileptic drug is deemed safe in pregnancy
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1 and 4 Explanation: In the given clinical scenario abrupt stopping of antiepileptic drugs when once used in pregnancy is not recommended due to the high risk to the fetus due to uncontrolled seizures which result in anoxia and intellectual disability. Antiepileptic has to be continued, and then the dose can be tapered slowly if there are no episodes of seizures. Management of seizures in pregnancy If the patient has had a history of seizures and is on any antiepileptic drug, the same prescribed drug is continued. If the first episode occurs during pregnancy, the drug preferred is either Lamotrigine or Levetiracetam. Folic acid ( 4mg/day ) should be given to all. No anti-epileptic drug is deemed safe in pregnancy. So, it is important to have the patient on monotherapy at the lowest effective dose, especially during the first trimester. Antiepileptic drug Associated malformation Valproate Neural tube defects Cardiac defects Cleft lip Cleft palate Developmental delay ADHD Phenytoin Fetal Hydantoin syndrome Cranio- facial anomalies Fingernail hypoplasia Developmental delay Cardiac anomalies Phenobarbital Cleft lip and palate Cardiac anomalies UT malformations Levetiracetam Skeletal abnormalities Lamotrigine Cleft lip/palate Topiramate Cleft lip/palate Carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine Fetal hydantoin syndrome Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 166. Antiepileptic drugs

questions.question: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents to the emergency department following a severe motor vehicle accident. She is stable but requires an urgent CT imaging of her pelvis to rule out internal injuries. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the pelvic area. The estimated fetal radiation exposure from a pelvic CT scan is 1 rad. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: Perform a fetal MRI to assess for any structural abnormalities.
options.C: Reassure the patient that the fetal dose is within acceptable limits and continue prenatal care.
options.D: Proceed with the pelvic CT scan.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Proceed with the pelvic CT scan. Explanation: The most appropriate next step would be to proceed with the CT of Pelvis as it is necessary to rule out internal injuries and the radiation exposure is 1 rad which is acceptable radiation in pregnancy Deterministic effect of ionising radiation in pregnancy: Gestational Age (weeks) <5 rad 5–10 rad >10 rad 0-2 None None None 3-4 None Probably None Low risk of spontaneous abortion 5-10 None Not clinically detectable Possible malformations 11-17 None Not clinically detectable Risk of decreased IQ or of mental retardation 18-27 None None IQ deficits not detectable at diagnostic doses >27 None None None Reference: Williams obstetrics, Edition 26, Page: 871 DC Dutta Obstetrics, Edition 9, Page: 607

questions.question: During a routine prenatal examination at 36 weeks gestation, a pregnant woman complains of occasional abdominal discomfort and pressure. On palpation, the obstetrician notes the fetal head is engaged in the pelvis. Which obstetric maneuver would be most appropriate to confirm the position of the fetal head?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Leopold's maneuver Explanation: Leopold's maneuver involves a sequence of palpations to determine the position of the fetus and its parts in the uterus . It is commonly used to confirm the fetal position and presentation during pregnancy by systematically assessing the fundal height, location of the fetal back, presenting part, and cephalic prominence or breech presentation. Leopold's Maneuver Position Technique Purpose Fundal Grip (First Leopold) Facing the patient’s face Palpate the fundal area with both hands Determine which fetal pole is in the fundus Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable Lateral or Umbilical Grip (Second Leopold) Facing the patient’s face Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time Identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder Back: Smooth, curved, resistant Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head Pawlik’s Grip (Third Leopold) Facing the patient’s face Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis Grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty Pelvic Grip (Fourth Leopold) Facing the patient’s feet Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward Identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement Head Characteristics: Precise presenting area Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput) Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips) Pinard maneuver (Option B): Pinard’s maneuver (Frank breech extraction) is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footling breech. Mc Roberts maneuver (Option C): Used during delivery to relieve shoulder dystocia. Ritgen maneuver (Option D): Used during delivery to prevent perineal tearing.

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. She has a history of gestational diabetes, and her pregnancy has been otherwise uneventful. The doctor decides to perform antepartum fetal surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess the fetal well-being in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Non-Stress test Explanation: The NST is a noninvasive, quick, and reliable method for assessing fetal heart rate response to fetal movements, which is crucial given the reported decrease in fetal movements. During an NST, the mother is placed in a comfortable position, and external monitors are attached to her abdomen to record the fetal heart rate and any fetal movements for 20-30 minutes. A reactive NST (presence of accelerations in fetal heart rate with movements) indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive NST (lack of sufficient accelerations) may necessitate further testing or intervention. Antepartum fetal surveillance: Fetal movement Maternal observation and recording of fetal movements to assess fetal well-being and activity levels. Non-stress test (NST) Monitors fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements to assess fetal well-being. Biophysical profile (BPP) (Option B ruled out) Assesses fetal well-being based on fetal heart rate accelerations, fetal movements, muscle tone, breathing movements, and amniotic fluid volume Doppler velocimetry Uses ultrasound to assess blood flow in fetal vessels like umbilical artery, middle cerebral artery (MCA), and ductus venosus, aiding in the evaluation of fetal well-being and placental function Amniotic fluid index (AFI) (Option A ruled out) Measures the depth of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being and detect potential complications like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios Contraction stress test (CST) (Option C ruled out) Evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions to assess fetal well-being and uteroplacental function under controlled stress conditions. BPP, CST, and AFI are not the initial tests that are performed as they are either invasive ( CST) or time-consuming ( BPP ) or do not properly tell us about fetal movements( AFI ). Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 386-391.

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 24 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for a routine prenatal visit. She has no significant medical history and reports feeling well, with normal fetal movements. Which method would be most appropriate for monitoring fetal heart sounds at this stage of her pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hand held doppler Explanation: Hand held doppler is the most appropriate method for monitoring fetal heart sounds at 24 weeks of gestation. Hand held doppler is capable of detecting fetal heart sounds as early as 10-12 weeks of gestation and is widely used during routine prenatal visits throughout pregnancy. It is non-invasive, safe, easy to use, and provides immediate feedback on fetal heart rate and well-being. Hand held doppler Detect and amplify fetal heart sounds, typically starting around 10-12 weeks of gestation Fetoscope A specialized stethoscope designed for listening directly to fetal heart sounds through the maternal abdomen, usually used after 18-20 weeks of gestation. Electronic Fetal Monitoring (EFM) Continuous or intermittent electronic monitoring of fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during labor using external or internal sensors Fetal Phonocardiography A method that records and analyzes fetal heart sounds to assess cardiac function and detect abnormalities, sometimes used in research or specialized clinical settings. Although Fetoscope (Option A) is used from 18 weeks gestation onwards, it’s less commonly used compared to doppler. EFM (Option B) is typically reserved for continuous monitoring during labor or in high-risk pregnancies where detailed and continuous assessment of fetal heart rate and uterine contractions is needed.It’s not practical for prenatal visits with healthy fetal movements. NST (Option D) is not typically used as a primary method for routine monitoring of fetal heart sounds at 24 weeks without any specific concerns. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 182, 387, 415

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines can a pregnant woman receive?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Influenza Explanation: The influenza vaccine is recommended for all pregnant women in any trimester during the flu season. Others are live attenuated vaccines, which are contraindicated in pregnancy. Vaccines contraindicated in pregnancy (Option A, C and D) Measles Mumps Rubella Varicella Smallpox Zoster Used in high risk of contracting infection Polio Yellow fever Influenza (Option B) Rabies Hepatitis B Hepatitis A Pneumococcus Meningococcus Typhoid Anthrax Not recommended HPV Recommeneded Tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 189, 190.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman at 16 weeks of gestation presents to her obstetrician. The quad test had shown an elevated risk for Down’s syndrome. How to make a definitive diagnosis of Down’s syndrome in the fetus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Amniocentesis Explanation: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for genetic diseases done after 15 weeks of pregnancy. Done when the screening tests are positive. Prenatal genetic screening: First trimester Second trimester Timing 11 - 14 weeks 15 - 22 weeks Screening test (Option A and B ruled out ) PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A) Free beta-hCG Ultrasound measurement of Nuchal translucency (NT) and nasal bone Quad test: Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP) Unconjugated estriol (uE3) Dimeric inhibin-A hCG If NT is ≥ 3 mm in the first trimester - ultrasound and fetal echocardiography Note: The best screening procedure is to combine the first and second-trimester tests. Prenatal genetic diagnostic tests (done when the screening tests are positive): Chorionic Villus Sampling Amniocentesis Cordocentesis Timing Transcervical:10–13 weeks Transabdominal:10 weeks to term After 15 weeks (Option C) 18–20 weeks (Option D ruled out) Materials for study Trophoblast cells Fetal fibroblasts Fetal white blood cells Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 114. DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 103, 104.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with active labor. She is gravida 2, para 1, with a previous history of a cesarean section. She has a singleton pregnancy at 39 weeks gestation, and her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On examination, she is in spontaneous labor with a cephalic presentation. According to Robson’s classification, which group does she belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Group 5 Explanation: Robson criteria is used as the global standard for assessing, monitoring and comparing cesarean delivery rates within and between healthcare facilities. Group 5 includes women with a previous cesarean section with a single cephalic pregnancy at ≥ 37 weeks. Group Description 1 Nullipara, single, cephalic, term pregnancy, spontaneous labour 2 (Option A ruled out) Nullipara, single, cephalic, term, induced labour or planned Cesarean section (CS) 3 (Option B ruled out) Multipara without uterine scar, single, cephalic, term, spontaneous labour 4 (Option C ruled out) Multipara without uterine scar, single, cephalic, term, induced labour or planned CS 5 (Option D) Multipara with uterine scar, single, cephalic, term 6 Nullipara, single, Breech presentation 7 Multipara, single, breech, including previous CS 8 Multiple Pregnancy 9 Single, abnormal lie, including previous scar 10 Single, Cephalic, Preterm including previous scar Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25866355/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7931279 /

questions.question: A 36-year-old woman who is currently 19 weeks pregnant. She missed her first-trimester screening and is now anxious about the possibility of her baby having a chromosomal abnormality, given her advanced maternal age. She comes for her second-trimester screening appointment. A quadruple marker test was ordered and it returned with a positive result for suspected Down’s syndrome. Which of the following results corresponds to Down’s syndrome? A. ↓ AFP, ↓ hCG, ↓ uE3 B. ↓ AFP, ↓ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↓ Inhibin A C. ↓ AFP, ↑ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↑ Inhibin A D. ↑ AFP, ↑ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↑ Inhibin A
questions.explanation: ↓ AFP, ↑ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↑ Inhibin A Correct Answer: C) ↓ AFP, ↑ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↑ Inhibin A Explanation: Quadruple Marker Down’s Syndrome (Option C) Edward’s Syndrome (Option A ruled out) Patau’s Syndrome (Option B ruled out) Alpha Feto-Protein (AFP) ↓ ↓ ↓ Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) ↑ ↓ ↓ Unconjugated Estriol (uE3) ↓ ↓ ↓ Inhibin A ↑ - ↓ Note: Inhibin A is not taken into calculation for Edward’s Syndrome. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 338.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents for her routine prenatal check-up. She is currently 11 weeks pregnant and feeling anxious about her pregnancy due to her age and the risk of chromosomal abnormalities associated with it. During a fetal aneuploidy screening, risk of Trisomy 21 is increased. What would be the levels of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) and Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) in Trisomy 21?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Increased hCG and Decreased PAPP-A. Explanation: Trisomy 21 is characterized by increased hCG and decreased PAPP-A. First Trimester Aneuploidy screening includes: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) Nuchal Translucency (NT) on UltraSonoGram (USG) Increased NT is more commonly associated with cardiac abnormalities than trisomies. Therefore, a fetal echocardiogram is recommended when NT measurement is >3.5 mm. Trisomy 18 and 13 are characterized by decreased hCG and decreased PAPP-A. (Option B ruled out). Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 337.

questions.question: What are the minimum number of antenatal care (ANC) visits according to WHO and Government of India respectively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 8 & 4 Explanation: WHO Recommended Minimum ANC visits: 8 Govt. Of India Recommended Minimum ANC Visits: 4 Ideal number of visits: 13 or 14 1st Trimester - 1 visit. (within 12 weeks of gestation) 1st visit- <12 weeks Upto 7 months: once every month 2nd Trimester - 2 visits. (weeks - 20 & 26) 2nd visit- 14-26 weeks 8th month: twice every month 3rd Trimester - 5 visits. (weeks - 30, 34, 36, 38 & 40) 3rd visit- 28-32 weeks 9th month: Once every week 4th visit- 36 weeks to term Reference: World Health Organisation - https://www.who.int/news/item/07-11-2016-new-guidelines-on-antenatal-c are-for-a-positive-pregnancy-experience#:~:text=It%20recommends%20pregnant%20women%20to,38%20and%20 40%20weeks'%20gestation National Health Mission - https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/stg/pregnancy-care.pdf

questions.question: A 24-year-old primigravida with no high-risk behavior comes to the OPD for her first antenatal visit. Which among the following investigations are not done routinely on the first visit?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gonococcal screening Explanation: Gonococcal Screening is only done on high risk women who are to be screened in the first prenatal visit and again on the third visit. First Visit History Complete history  Physical Examination Complete  Blood pressure  Maternal weight  Pelvic/cervical examination  Fundal height  Fetal heart rate/fetal position  Laboratory Tests Hematocrit or hemoglobin  Blood type and Rh factor  Antibody screen  Pap smear screening  Fetal aneuploidy screening a B and/or Cystic fibrosis screening B or Urine protein assessment  Urine culture  Rubella serology ( Option D ruled out )  Syphilis serology ( Option C ruled out )  Gonococcal screening ( Option A ) D Chlamydial screening  Hepatitis B serology ( Option B ruled out )  HIVserology B First-trimester aneuploidy screening may be offered between 10 and 14 weeks A. Performed at 28 weeks if indicated B. Tests should be offered D. High-risk women should be screened at the first prenatal visit & in the third trimester Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 178

questions.question: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)? endometrial cavity.

options.A: Fetal pole and cardiac activity can be determined within 5-6 weeks using TVS
options.B: The double decidual sign is a potential indicator for early intra-uterine pregnancy
options.C: Gestational sac is the first sonographic evidence of pregnancy and is seen in the middle of the
options.D: Gestational sac may be seen as early as Upto 4-5 weeks of gestation with TVS

questions.explanation: middle of the endometrial cavity. Correct Answer: C) Gestational sac is the first sonographic evidence of pregnancy and is seen in the middle of the endometrial cavity. Explanation: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium and not in the midline. Transvaginal sonography (TVS) : Establish gestational age and confirm pregnancy location. More sensitive than Transabdominal sonography. Structure identification: Structure Timing Gestational sac (1 st sonographic evidence of pregnancy) (Option D ruled out) 4-5 weeks Yolk sac 5.5 weeks Fetal pole and cardiac activity (Option A ruled out) 5-6 weeks Intrauterine Pregnancy indicators: Eccentric implantation of normal gestational sac in endometrium (pseudosac is seen in the midline). (Option C) Intradecidual sign: Anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim Double decidual sign: Two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. (Option B ruled out ) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 177 DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 63

questions.question: A lady who is 24 weeks pregnant came to the OPD for routine antenatal check up. She has a history of normal twin delivery 3 years back and 2 abortions. What is is her obstetric score?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) G4P1A2L2 Explanation: In this case scenario G (gravida)- present pregnancy + twin pregnancy + 2 abortions = 4 P (parity)- twin pregnancy =1 A (abortion)- 2 abortions = 2 L (living)- twins = 2 The obstetric score includes: Gravida Denotes a pregnant state, both present and past, irrespective ofthe period of gestation Parity Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks) Abortion Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks Living Living children Note: Twin pregnancy counts as one for both gravida and parity. Reference: https://nhm.hp.gov.in/storage/app/media/uploaded-files/mtp-amendment-act2021.pdf

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was recorded as February 15, 2024. She reports regular 28-day menstrual cycles. What is her estimated delivery date (EDD)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) November 22, 2024 Explanation: EDD in this scenario: February 15 (LMP) + 7 days - 3 months = November 22, 2024. Calculation of the expected date of delivery (EDD) is done according to Naegele's formula by adding 7 days to the first day of the last period and subtracting 3 months or by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period. Note: In longer interval cycles (>28 days), extra days are to be added while, in shorter interval (<28 days) cycles, lesser days are subtracted to get the EDD. Pregnancies conceived by assisted reproductive technologies (IVF) date of LMP is 14 days prior to date of embryo transfers (266 days). Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 178-179 DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 88
